Package nl.fw.yapool

Yet Another Pool - a generic pool implementation

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    IPool<T>
    Main interface for all pool implementations.
    IPoolEvents
    Generic interface for handling IPoolListeners and PoolEvents.
    IPoolFactory<T>
    A factory for creating resources.
    IPoolListener
    Listener that can be added to a IPoolEvents registry to receive PoolEvents.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    BeanClone
    Utility methods for (un)serializing and (un)gzipping objects.
    BeanClone.GZIPBestOutputStream
    A GZIPOutputStream that uses Deflater.BEST_COMPRESSION.
    BeanConfig
    Methods for configuring pools and (SQL) pool-factories using key-value maps or properties.
    BoundPool<T>
    A LIFO pool that respects a minimum and maximum size.
    Pool<T>
    A LIFO pool that can be used to re-use resources.
    PoolEvent
    Event that is fired when a pool performs an action.
    PoolEvents
    Generic class for handling pool-events.
    PoolPruner
    A singleton pool-pruner that can prune multiple pools.
    PoolUsageLogger
    Logs a pruned pool's performance at regular intervals using all readily available counters and sizes (there is no performance impact on the pool itself).
    PrunedPool<T>
    A BoundPool that can actively remove idled and expired resources from the pool (see PrunedPool.prune()).
    PruneTask
    A default prune task that prunes a pool at regular intervals (uses PrunedPool.getPruneIntervalMs()).
    ThreadExecutor
    An executor-service that creates and starts a new thread for each new task.

Package nl.fw.yapool Description

Yet Another Pool - a generic pool implementation

This package provides 3 pool implementations (each extending the other).
All pools:

  • use a IPoolFactory (type-safe via Java Generics) to create, validate and destroy pooled resources.
  • fire PoolEvents so that custom actions can be executed (see for example PoolResourcePerformance).
  • use Java Concurrent to run fast and reliable.

Following 3 pool implementations are provided:

  • Basic: provides an object re-use capability.
  • Bound: ensures a limit to the amount of resources used.
  • Pruned: keeps resources in the pool healthy.

One of the most challenging types of pools is a database connection pool, this has been implemented in the nl.fw.yapool.sql package. Using the proxies technique, SqlPool is available as datasource in the nl.fw.yapool.sql.datasource package. This allows the SqlPool to be used with Hibernate 3 and 4 (see the projects yapool-hib3 and yapool-hib4) and Tomcat (see DataSourceFactory).

A generic object pool implementation is available in the nl.fw.yapool.object package.

The package nl.fw.yapool.socket contains an example of how to manage the amount of work that is done in a standard Java threadpool in relation with a server socket. As such, it contains an example of when the use of a pool (other then the threadpool) is not needed and when, in this case, a simple atomic integer will do the trick. The (simple) server socket implementation (SocketAcceptor) also contains a number of best practices which make it suitable for a production environment.

Last but not least, a large number of tests are available that not only touch most of the main source code, but also demonstrate the capabilities of yapool.
